channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Israeli Official Describes Secret Government Bid to Cement Control of West Bank
item.description: Israeli judges have long ruled that Israel’s control of the territory is a temporary military occupation and complies with international law. A powerful minister’s recent speech, caught on tape, suggested the government is trying to change that.

item.title: Israeli Official Describes Secret Government Bid to Cement Control of West Bank
item.description: Israeli judges have long ruled that Israel’s control of the territory is a temporary military occupation and complies with international law. A powerful minister’s recent speech, caught on tape, suggested the government is trying to change that.

item.title: Olive Garden owner’s CEO says fast food is so expensive you might as well have a sit-down meal
item.description: McDonald’s and Wendy’s have vexed budget-conscious consumers, and chains like Chili’s and Olive Garden are ready to take advantage.

item.title: Is Missouri About to Execute an Innocent Man?
item.description: The case against Marcellus Williams is far from settled.

item.title: Ángeles Flórez Peón, Spanish Civil War’s Last Militiawoman, Dies at 105
item.description: She was revered as an essential guardian of the country’s memory of war and repression long after the Franco dictatorship.

item.title: Say goodbye to the 20% down payment. Zillow says you’ll need to put down roughly 35%, or almost $128,000, to afford a typical home
item.description: In Los Angeles, a median-income household would need to put roughly 80% down to afford a typical home and its monthly payments in the city, according to Zillow.

item.title: Heat Waves: Workers May Die. Here’s How to Save Them.
item.description: Laws aren’t keeping pace with the risks climate change poses to workers laboring under sweltering conditions.

item.title: Swiss Court Convicts Hinduja Family of Exploiting Domestic Workers
item.description: A Swiss criminal court handed prison sentences to members of the Hinduja family for exploiting domestic workers at their villa in Geneva.

item.title: Supreme Court upholds ‘common sense’ law banning domestic abusers from gun possession in 8-1 decision
item.description: A week after overturning a ban on bump stocks, the court allowed a law than bans guns for people under restraining orders.

item.title: The Folger Library Wants to Reintroduce You to Shakespeare
item.description: After an $80 million expansion, the Folger Shakespeare Library is reopening with a more welcoming approach — and all 82 of its First Folios on view.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Much of Rafah Lies in Ruins as Israeli Forces Push Deeper Into the City
item.description: As Israeli strikes batter other parts of the Gaza Strip, the most intense action on the ground is the battle with Hamas fighters for control of Rafah.

item.title: Incoming Washington Post editor won’t take the job after newsroom revolt: ‘The body is rejecting the transfusion’
item.description: Post staff had revolted at the leadership change. “The body is rejecting the transfusion,” one said.

item.title: A Vape Pen, a Fall and a Question That Won’t Go Away: Why Did Nico Die?
item.description: Nico Nuño-Kelley, 17, fell six stories from the roof of his Manhattan apartment building after vaping marijuana. His anguished family wants answers.

item.title: Oil Projects Must Consider Full Climate Impact, Top U.K. Court Rules
item.description: Previously, local council and planning groups in Britain had to weigh only the planet-warming emissions from their own operations.

item.title: 90% of C-suite executives believe their company promotes worker well-being. Why do only 60% of workers agree?
item.description: The third annual Workplace Well-being report from Deloitte indicates a major gulf in understanding between executives and employees.
